contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | name = Inca Tern | status = NT | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref>{{IUCN|id=106003300 |title=''Larosterna inca'' |assessors=[[BirdLife International]] |version=2012.1 |year=2012 |accessdate=16 July 2012}}</ref> | image = Larosterna inca (Inca Tern - Inkaseeschwalbe) Weltvogelpark Walsrode 2012-015.jpg | image_width = | image_caption = Inca Tern at [[Walsrode Bird Park]], Germany, eating a fish | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordate|Chordata]] | classis = [[bird|Aves]] | ordo = [[Charadriiformes]] | familia = [[Sternidae]] | genus = '''''Larosterna''''' | genus_authority = [[Edward Blyth|Blyth]], 1852 | species = '''''L. inca''''' | binomial = ''Larosterna inca'' | binomial_authority = ([[Rene Primevere Lesson|Lesson]], 1827) }} The ''' Inca Tern''' (''Larosterna inca'') is a [[seabird]] in the family [[Sternidae]]. It is the [[Monotypic taxon|only member]] of the genus ''Larosterna''. This uniquely plumaged [[bird]] breeds on the coasts of [[Peru]] and [[Chile]], and is restricted to the [[Humboldt current]]. It can be identified by its dark grey body, white moustache on the both sides of its head, and red-orange [[beak]] and feet. ==Description== [[File:Larosterna inca -Lima, Peru -family-8.jpg|left|thumb|A family in [[Lima]], Peru]] The Inca Tern is a large tern, aproximately 40 cm long. Sexes are similar; the adult is mostly slate-grey with white restricted to the facial plumes and the trailing edges of the wings. The large bill and legs are dark red. Immature birds are purple-brown, and gradually develop the facial plumes. ==Behaviour== ===Breeding=== The Inca Tern breeds on rocky cliffs. It [[bird nest|nests]] in a hollow or [[burrow]] or sometimes the old nest of a [[Humboldt Penguin]], and lays one or two [[bird egg|eggs]]. The eggs are incubated for about 4 weeks, and the chicks leave the nest after 7 weeks.<ref name ="LPZIncaTern">[http://www.lpzoo.org/animals/factsheet/inca-tern "Inca Tern Fact Sheet, Lincoln Park Zoo"]</ref> ===Feeding=== The Inca tern feeds primarily on small fish, such as anchovies. The species spots its prey from the air, diving into the water to grab meals with its pointed beak.<ref name ="LPZIncaTern" /> Its call is a [[cat|cat-like]] ''mew''. ==References== {{Reflist}} * Harrison, Peter (1988): ''Seabirds (2nd edition)''. Christopher Helm, London ISBN 0-7470-1410-8 ==External links== *[http://mundoazul.org/habitats-species/marine-birds/inca-tern/ Mundo Azul Species Factsheet: Inca tern] {{Commons|Larosterna inca}} [[Category:Sternidae]] [[Category:Bird genera]] [[Category:Monotypic bird genera]] [[Category:Birds of Peru]] [[Category:Animals described in 1827]]
